'''L. C. McKinley''' (October 22, 1918 – January 19, 1970)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1970.html |title=The 1970s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] guitarist. He worked with both [[Eddie Boyd]] and Ernest Cotton.<ref name="Dead"/> A performer on the Chicago blues scene, McKinley's major output was as a [[session musician]] on recordings primarily cut in the 1950s.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|last=Leggett |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lc-mckinley-mn0001225783 |title=L.C. McKinley - Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref>

McKinley also released a number of [[Single (music)|singles]] on various [[record label]]s.<ref name="AMG"/> His best known tracks included "Weeping Willow Blues" and "Nit Wit."<ref name="Dead"/> His guitar playing was influenced by [[T-Bone Walker]].<ref name="speedylive1">{{cite web|url=http://www.speedylive.net/live/xufbf7aja_0/LC-McKinley-Sharpest-Man-In-Town |title=L.C. McKinley Sharpest Man In Town|publisher=Speedylive.net |date=1969-01-19 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> 

==Biography==
He was born '''Larry McKinley''' in [[Winona, Mississippi]], United States.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead"/> According to the [[United States Census]] in 1940, McKinley was living in [[Vaiden, Mississippi]], with his wife, Bessie, and two sons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ancestry.com/1940-census/usa/Mississippi/L-C-McKinley_4583jm |title=L C McKinley in the 1940 Census |publisher=Ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> However, McKinley relocated to Chicago in 1941.<ref name="AMG"/> He began to get work and, by 1947, had started to play professionally in the Chicago area.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="States"/> By the early 1950s, McKinley was a regular performer at the 708 Club, where he variously topped the bill or played accompaniment in the first half of 1954 with the Ernest Cotton Trio.<ref name="States"/>

He began a working association with [[Eddie Boyd]] in the early 1950s and, in 1952, McKinley and Cotton backed Boyd on the latter's recording of "[[Five Long Years]]".<ref name="AMG"/> It reached number one on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]].<ref>
{{Cite book
  | last = Whitburn
  | first = Joel
  | authorlink = 
  | coauthors = 
  | title = Top R&B Singles 1942–1988
  | publisher = Record Research, Inc
  | series = 
  | volume =
  | edition = 
  | date = 1988
  | location = 
  | page = 52
  | language = 
  | url = 
  | doi = 
  | id = 
  | isbn =0-89820-068-7
  | mr = 
  | zbl = 
  | jfm = }}
</ref> McKinley also undertook recording sessions with several of Chicago's better known blues musicians, including [[Curtis Jones (pianist)|Curtis Jones]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1953 he recorded for Parrot Records, although his work was not released.<ref name="Sunday">{{cite web|url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/tag/vee-jay-records |title=Vee-Jay Records | Big Road Blues |publisher=Sundayblues.org |date=2008-09-14 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> He signed to [[States Records]] in January 1954, who issued his "Companion Blues" later that year.<ref name="States"/>

In 1955, McKinley penned a [[recording contract]] with [[Vee-Jay Records]].<ref name="Sunday"/> His single "Strange Girl" / "She's Five Feet Three" was issued by them the same year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/L-C-McKinley-Strange-Girl-Shes-Five-Feet-Three/release/1047759 |title=L C McKinley* - Strange Girl / She's Five Feet Three (Vinyl) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> Other tracks he recorded in that period, but were unissued at that time, included "Blue Evening", "Down With It", "Rosalie Blues", "Disgusted", and "Tortured Blues".<ref name="States">{{cite web|url=http://koti.mbnet.fi/wdd/lcmckinley.htm |title=WangDangDula.com |publisher=Koti.mbnet.fi |date=2010-05-08 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/unitedstates2.html |title=The United and States Labels Part II (1954-1957) |publisher=Hubcap.clemson.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> In 1959, Bea & Baby Records released his single "Nit Wit".<ref name="States"/>

McKinley made his last recordings in 1964, and they were released on the Sunnyland label in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].<ref name="speedylive1"/>

After leaving the [[music industry]], he latterly worked as a presser for a [[dry cleaning]] outfit in [[East Chicago, Indiana]].<ref name="States"/>

McKinley died in East Chicago in January 1970, aged 51.<ref name="Dead"/>
